text: Atopy , which predisposes individuals to develop asthma , severe systemic anaphylaxis , and atopic dermatitis , is usually associated with dramatically elevated total serum IgE levels and is thought to be controlled by a major susceptibility gene and multiple minor susceptibility genes .
A recent sib - pair analysis revealed a tight linkage between markers on 5q31.1 and a major susceptibility gene controlling total serum IgE levels .

Due to its location within this cluster and its biologic role in Ig class switching and Th2 cell differentiation , the <extra_id_0> IL-4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene has emerged as one major candidate for the atopy gene .

In one model , polymorphisms within <extra_id_0> IL-4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> regulatory elements might result in overexpression of the gene , amplifying Th2 cell differentiation and class switching to IgE .

text: In support of this model , we report that the human <extra_id_0> IL-4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter exists in multiple allelic forms that exhibit distinct transcriptional activities in <extra_id_0> IL-4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - positive T cells .

text: A particular allele has an unusually high transcriptional activity .

A nucleotide substitution within a recently described OAP40 element located just upstream of an NF-AT site ( P sequence ) appears to be largely responsible for the increased promotor strength of this particular allelic form of the <extra_id_0> IL-4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter .
In EMSAs , this substitution results in a markedly enhanced affinity for sequence - specific complexes exhibiting an AP-1 specificity .

The identification of allelic nucleotides , which results in overexpression of the <extra_id_0> IL-4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene , provides specific targets for a comprehensive screening of atopic and nonatopic individuals and may provide a clue for genetic predisposition for atopy .
